awd_titl_txt: Kinetics and stability of redox-active organics for electrochemical systems
awd_abstract_narration:
Redox flow batteries (RFBs) are large-scale energy storage systems that enable the use of intermittent renewable energy resources, such as solar and wind power, which may not always be available when energy is being consumed. Unlike other battery technologies, RFBs can store significant amounts of energy in fluids stored in large reservoirs that are then flowed through cells to insert (i.e. charge) or to extract energy (i.e. discharge) from the system. Aqueous flow batteries employing dissolved organic redox active compounds (materials that can pick up and give off electrons) might safely and inexpensively store and deliver large amounts of electrical energy. These materials are environmentally benign, inflammable, and can be designed for low-cost production through modern, large-scale chemical synthesis technologies. However, chemical stability currently limits their long-term use in energy storage installations. This research project addresses fundamental understanding of the charge-discharge energy properties and degradation pathways of these energy-storing materials. The fundamental knowledge gained will also contribute towards other redox-based chemical processes, CO2 capture technologies and other electron-transfer processes relevant to biology. The project also continues a relationship with Boston's Museum of Science on a partnership to provide interactive presentations and content on the theme of renewable energy and its use in our nation's economy.

This fundamental research project will explore the thermodynamic stability and electrochemical kinetics of small organic molecules such as quinones in aqueous electrolytes. The use application is to understand chemical and electrochemical degradation at a mechanistic level.  In aqueous solutions, some quinones are known to undergo rapid and reversible two-electron reductions to hydroquinone; they form the basis for new RFB electrolytes with the potential for enhanced efficiency and reduced cost. However, even the best of these material systems experiences a slow loss of capacity that, in some cases, has been attributed to molecular degradation. The investigators have identified a number of degradation pathways including the formation of semiquinone radical intermediates from single-electron reduction and correlated these to permanent loss of cell performance. Furthermore, the PIs have observed dramatic changes in quinone electrochemical kinetics when dissolved in solutions of various pH electrolytes. This project is a cross-school collaboration between the Department of Chemistry and Chemical Biology and the School of Engineering and Applied Sciences. This research will investigate the influences of molecular structure, substituent groups, pH, oxidation state, and electrolyte salts on molecular thermodynamic stability and electrochemical kinetics for redox-active organic compounds. The team will synthesize new molecules designed to answer fundamental questions and will evaluate their thermodynamic and kinetic properties using specially designed electrochemical flow cells.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental, and Transport Systems

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: PRESIDENT AND FELLOWS OF HARVARD COLLEGE

por.por_cntn:
The most significant overall outcome is the development of sufficient understanding of decomposition mechanisms to inform the design and synthesis of such long-lived redox-active molecules that it was possible to set new world records for the lowest battery charge-storing capacity fade rate, in the absence of rebalancing  techniques, of any flow battery ever published -- organic or inorganic, aqueous or non-aqueous. Three case studies are highlighted below.

            High-performance anthraquinones. Through fundamental studies of the decomposition mechanisms of our redox-active anthraquinones, which we have been using for storing energy in flow batteries, we learned what causes molecular instability in aqueous electrolytes, thereby leading to loss over time of the charge storage capacity of a battery. We discovered that we could suppress the mechanisms of gem-diol formation and Michael attack by attaching solubilizing groups to the redox-active molecular core with atomic spacers between the solubilizing groups and the aryl rings, e.g. (aryl ring)-O-CH2-CH2-CH2-COO-. This left the predominant remaining decomposition mechanism as nucleophilic attack of the C-O-C linkage, breaking off the solubilizing arms and causing precipitation. We recently developed a way to suppress this nucleophilic attack mechanism by replacing the C-O-C linkage with C-C-C linkages which are remarkably inert. We did this by starting from anthracene, a less expensive precursor than could be utilized previously, and developing a new synthetic approach for two extremely stable anthraquinone negolyte (negative electrolyte) species, called  DPivOHAQ and DBAQ, which demonstrated record low capacity fade rates of 5% and 3% per year, respectively. By this method we could produce molecules that could not be produced previously and, in some cases, at lower cost. Subsequently, we introduced electron-donating atomic groups to increase cell voltage by lowering negolyte redox potential and we introduced chiral substituents to raise solubility by frustrating crystallographic packing – both without C-O-C linkages, maintaining molecular decomposition rates <10%/yr.

            Progress in posolyte active species. Ferro/ferricyanide, due to its complete structural stability at neutral to alkaline pH, is the preferred posolyte (positive electrolyte) species for aqueous flow batteries. Its redox potential, 0.44 V vs. Standard Hydrogen Electrode, is modest, as is its solubility (0.2-1.4 moles per liter, i.e. up to 38 Ampere-hours per liter, depending on pH and cations). There have been many efforts to improve on these properties through organic and metalorganic synthesis, but none of those with higher redox potential than 0.44 V have been nearly stable enough for practical deployment, all fading at >70%/yr. We developed an iron coordination complex that operates at near neutral pH with a redox potential more than 0.5 V higher than that of ferro/ferricyanide, a capacity fade rate as low as 0.07%/day, and a solubility of about 1 M. With the lowest demonstrated capacity fade rate of any organic or metalorganic species with a redox potential greater than that of ferro/ferricyanide, it represents a major step forward in posolyte development. It is not the end of the road, however: a careful study in this work of decomposition mechanisms suggests that changing solubilizing groups to suppress ligand dissociation, possibly at the cost of voltage, may enable lifetimes to reach practical values.

            Electrochemical Regeneration. In a departure from prior research directions, we discovered an electrochemical method for converting the decomposition products of a redox-active organic molecule back to the original redox-active form. This permits an extension of the practical operating life of a flow battery but a factor of, so far, up to 20x. We plan for further exploration of this discovery in future research.

            Electrosynthesis. In another departure from prior research directions, we developed a new in situ electrochemical synthesis method for functionalized anthraquinones and showed that we could synthesize DPivOHAQ and DBAQ from electrochemical methods instead of the traditional thermochemical methods. The electrosynthesized products were used as the active species in a flow battery electrolyte; long-term cell cycling results for lifetimes were consistent with those published previously for the thermochemically synthesized molecules. Compared to conventional thermochemical and methods, the new method is safe and potentially inexpensive because it eliminates both the use of toxic and environmentally unfriendly oxidants and the necessity of post-synthesis isolation of the products from the supporting electrolytes. The as-generated electrolytes can be used immediately in a flow battery without separation or purification. We plan for further exploration of this discovery in future research.

 

 


Last Modified: 12/19/2022
Modified by: Michael J Aziz
